docTitle.titlePart: A novel calcineurin splice variant that modifies calcineurin activity

byline.docAuthor: Alexander Reuter, Jun Mi, Inken Sehrsam, Albert C. Ludolph and Helge Vö lkel

byline.affiliation: Department of Neurology, University of Ulm,

front.div:
Calcineurin is a Ca
21
/calmodulin dependent phosphopro-
tein phosphatase implicated in a wide range of disorders.
Here, we report the cloning of a novel calcineurin Aa splice
variant that lacks both the catalytic and calcineurin B
binding domains. Biochemical analysis revealed a stimulat-
ing effect on calcineurin activity at low calcium
concentrations as well as protein–protein interaction with
the catalytic calcineurin holoenzyme. By Western blot
analysis, expression of similar short splice variants could be
seen in the spinal cord of an animal model of familial
amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, suggesting a role of these new
variants in motor neuron disease.
front.keyword:
Keywords: calcineurin; splice variant; amyotrophic lateral
sclerosis; phosphatase.
front.div:
Calcineurin (EC 3.1.3.16), the only serine/threonine protein
phosphatase that is under the control of Ca
21
/calmodulin,
plays an important role in the coupling of Ca
21 signals to
cellular responses [1]. Although it is broadly expressed, it is
especially abundant in the nervous system where it accounts
for more than 1% of total protein [2]. Calcineurin becomes
activated by binding calcium and calmodulin when cytosolic
calcium levels rise, and is inhibited on binding the
immunosuppressants Cyclosporin A and FK506 in com-
plexes with their respective cellular receptors. Recently, a
family of conserved calcineurin regulators that inhibit
calcineurin has been described [3]. In addition, a role for
calcineurin has been discussed in several disorders such as
ischemia/reperfusion injury, cardiac hypertension, stroke,
and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis [4 –7].
Calcineurin is a heterodimer of a catalytic A subunit of
< 60 kDa and a regulatory B subunit of < 19 kDa [8]. So
far three isoforms of the A subunit are known, correspond-
ing to different genes: calcineurin Aa (PP3CA ) on
chromosome 4, calcineurin Ab (PP3CB ) on chromosome
10 and calcineurin Ag (PP3CC ) on chromosome 8. In
addition, all isoforms show alternative splicing resulting in
at least two splice variants per isoform. The A subunit has
five distinct domains: the N-terminal domain of so far
unknown function, the catalytic domain, the B-subunit
binding domain, the calmodulin-binding domain and the
auto-inhibitory domain. In this study, we report the cloning
and expression of a novel calcineurin Aa splice variant
CNAa16K that lacks the catalytic and the calcineurin B
binding domain. Although it possesses no phosphatase
activity on its own, this new isoform was able to stimulate
the phosphatase activity of purified calcineurin at low
calcium concentrations.
